awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research:  Physiological signatures of variable weaning strategies in wild primates
awd_abstract_narration:
Premature weaning can result in poor infant developmental outcomes and increased infant mortality; however, the social conditions that lead to premature weaning and its consequences are still poorly understood. The central goal of this project is to examine how stressful social conditions linked to the immigration of new adult males and/or poor maternal condition influence the likelihood of premature weaning, and, in turn how premature weaning then influences infant growth, gut microbial colonization, and the development of the immune system in a nonhuman primate model. Given the importance of early weaning as a hallmark of human evolution, developing comprehensive longitudinal models of this early life transition are valuable. In addition, the findings may serve as an animal model for understanding the costs and benefits of truncated or extended breastfeeding in modern humans. The project will provide rigorous scientific training to at least one post-doctoral fellow and several graduate and undergraduate students. The PIs will also engage in public outreach at local and international levels, contributing to scientific education and conservation efforts both domestically and abroad.  

This project examines the links between social factors, variable weaning strategies, and infant growth and immune system development in geladas. It draws on both cross-sectional and longitudinal data collected from infants aged 0-2.5 years to address the following goals: (1) Determine how social factors related to stressful demographic changes and/or maternal condition influence the timing of nursing cessation; (2) Identify how earlier weaning relative to infant size is related to stunted postnatal growth, altered gut microbial diversity and composition, and the concentration of urinary neopterin, a biomarker for cellular inflammation. Geladas are ideal for this research because their social system is characterized by frequent and stressful social upheavals that disrupt infant development and can even lead to infant mortality. Further, gelada females form strong dominance hierarchies that determine access to food, thus allowing researchers to address how social factors linked to poor maternal nutrition are associated with variable weaning strategies. Together, these attributes make geladas an excellent model system in which to study premature weaning. This study will be one of the first to integrate innovative methods in isotopic/elemental chemistry, genomics, endocrinology, and digital photogrammetry to examine the causes and consequences of premature weaning in wild primate infants, thus identifying some of the key mechanisms bridging early life social adversity to long-term developmental and health. Student trainees will have the opportunity to learn methods in behavioral data collection as well as various wet lab methods to characterize the composition of the gut microbiome and define weaning by the amount of milk vs. plant-origin carbon and nitrogen found in noninvasively collected fecal samples.

por.por_cntn:
Increasing research has identified the pre-weaning period as a critical developmental window for mammals, including humans. During this period, mothers continuously transfer milk to their infants, providing not only nutritional and immune benefits, but bioactives such as microbes that can alter infant development. Because of the crucial role of milk, infants that are not breastfed (as in humans) or are prematurely weaned could face disadvantages. Here we began to address the factors influencing infant health in a wild nonhuman primate model - the gelada (Theropithecus gelada), focusing specifically on early-life changes in the gut microbiota and how this relates to weaning. The gelada social structure – small reproductive units embedded in larger bands – allowed us to amass a sample size on infant health that was unprecedented in a wild primate. 


First, we presented the most comprehensive data on early-life gut microbiome maturation in a nonhuman model. We determined how maternal characteristics, particularly parity, influenced gut microbiome maturation. Second, we examined how gut microbiome composition was linked to biomarkers of inflammation. And fourth, we investigated whether social conditions could spur early maternal divestment, potentially setting up a good system to evaluate how naturalistic premature weaning could influence the infant gut microbiome and other aspects of infant health.


We found that maturation of the infant gelada microbiome bore close resemblance to the process in humans - with taxa diversifying quickly from birth until 7 months of life, and more gradual changes from 7 months until weaning (~17 months). Many of these changes were associated with diet; taxa that were functionally linked to processing milk were more abundant in early infancy, while those linked to metabolizing complex polysaccharides were more abundant when infants started incorporating solid foods (i.e., grass) into the diet. Like in humans, the cessation of nursing marked the point at which infant gelada microbiomes had reached their adult-like composition, supporting the unique role that lactation likely plays on infant gut microbial development. 


We found that infants of first-time mothers were characterized by a gut microbiome that was functionally less mature than infants of experienced mothers, reflecting a prolonged reliance on milk and a slower transition to microbes that metabolize complex polysaccharides. In addition, we found that once weaned, the juvenile gelada gut microbiome was more similar to its mothers than to other adult females in the population, suggesting that maternal effects on the gut microbiome persist past the nursing period.


In a related study, we examined how infancy was related to measures of inflammation and how the gut microbiome was related to these patterns. In general, non-specific immune responses are thought to be exaggerated in early-life as adaptive immune responses have not yet matured. We found that age predicted urinary neopterin concentrations (a biomarker of cellular inflammation) in a U-shaped pattern, with infants indeed having the highest concentrations. In addition, measures of gut microbiome alpha diversity (which are highest during early infancy) were negatively correlated with neopterin, such that low levels of diversity were associated with high inflammation. These results reinforce the idea that the early-life period is a sensitive period when developmental systems such as the immune system could be heavily impacted by the gut microbiome.


Finally, we took a behavioral approach to examine possible events that might perturb this sensitive infancy period. We took advantage of 15 years of gelada data showing that alpha male replacement in core reproductive groups results in changes in female physiology, including in the mating status of lactation females. We found that lactating female geladas returned to estrus earlier in response to an alpha male replacement, and that this change in reproductive physiology was accompanied by early weaning. Intriguingly, these changes were associated with increased infant survival, suggesting that the potential costs of maternal divestment were offset by survival benefits, presumably related to avoiding male aggression. Nevertheless, these results set the stage for future studies linking early changes in infant development (for instance, in the gut microbiome and immunity) to premature weaning. 


In sum, our project contributed one of the most comprehensive datasets on early gut microbiome development and associated inflammatory profiles in a wild primate species. Using behavioral and demographic data, we also confirmed the social pressures that might influence maternal investment in lactation, thus setting the stage for future studies on premature weaning. Given the current debates on breastfeeding and its effects on infant health through the gut microbiome, our research has provided timely data on the microbiome effects of nursing in a naturalistic population where individual differences remain salient, despite the fact that all animals nurse. These data suggest that the differences in humans, who practice variable nursing strategies, must be substantially greater – with potential downstream effects on health.
